intro: Gilia maculata, commonly known as the spotted gilia, is an annual herbaceous plant native to the western United States. It typically grows to a height of 15–30 centimeters and features slender stems covered in fine hairs. The plant produces clusters of small, showy flowers that range in color from white to pink and are often speckled with purple or red markings. Its leaves are alternate, lance-shaped, and have a slightly hairy texture. Gilia maculata thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in disturbed habitats such as roadsides and open fields.
